title: MyPillow CEO Mike Lindell Expects Ads to Appear on Fox News Again
summary: Company had pulled its ads after network declined to air commercial linked to Mr. Lindell's efforts to claim the 2020 election was rigged. The monthslong standoff between Fox News and one of its biggest advertisers is beginning to thaw.

title: Democrats Keep Playing the Trump Card to Win Elections
summary: It worked for them in 2020 and the California recall election, and they're trying it again in Virginia's race for governor this November.. Joe Biden and the Democratic Party won in 2020 by campaigning on two main issues: Donald Trump's personality and his administration's handling of Covid-19. Today, Democrats are doubling down on that strategy. They realize that the specter of the former president will be more effective than any policy at turning out Democratic voters in next year's midterm elections.

title: Pfizer, FedEx, Nike: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Pfizer Inc .

title: Theranos Lab Director Describes Raising Alarms About Faulty Tests
summary: Dr. Adam Rosendorff testifies that company cared more about PR and money than patients. Theranos Inc.'s former lab director testified Friday about what he called pervasive and persistent errors in the company's blood-testing technology and his efforts to stop the startup from using its machines on real patients.

title: Rochelle Walensky's Finest Hour
summary: The CDC chief made the right call on Covid booster shots.. The Biden Administration's booster vaccine plan has been messy and confusing, but at least it arrived at the right outcome. Credit to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention director Rochelle Walensky late Thursday for overruling the agency's outside advisers and backing a broad booster rollout.

title: Vindication Over Hunter's Emails
summary: Politico confirms the New York Post story the Bidens never denied.. The New York Post is claiming vindication over its scoop in October 2020 about Hunter Biden's emails, and deservedly so. But that shouldn't be the end of the story for everyone who attacked the Post or ignored the story to cover for Joe Biden.

title: White House 'Zero' Hour
summary: His spending blowout in jeopardy, Biden claims the cost is 'nothing.'. Democrats in Congress are proving to be harder to corral behind a $3.5 trillion multiplicity of tax increases and entitlement expansions than their leaders had hoped. So behold the new White House spin: The agenda that was being sold a few weeks ago as the modern equivalent of the New Deal or Great Society is actually so modest it doesn't cost a thing.

title: A Green Energy Texas Whitewash
summary: The federal report on the winter power outage ignores some key facts.. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) on Thursday issued its long-awaited report on Texas's winter power outage. Why did it take so long? Chairman Richard Glick's foregone conclusion was that renewables were not to blame no matter the evidence.

title: 'Jasper Johns: Mind/Mirror' Review: Twice as Nice
summary: A pair of linked retrospectives running simultaneously in New York and Philadelphia lay out the long and varied career of the iconic American artist.. New York and Philadelphia

title: 'Melvin Van Peebles: Essential Films' Review: Celebrating a Maverick
summary: The pioneering Black filmmaker, who died Tuesday, gets a Criterion release..

title: The Sixth-Best Feeling
summary: My 10-year-old son is serious about his rankings-but not too serious.. I called my father one Sunday morning, on my family's drive home from church. He asked how the Carolina Panthers were doing, and I said I hadn't been paying close attention. This was something my 10-year-old son, Jack, found shocking. "Coming home from church, eating lunch and spending the afternoon watching football is the sixth-best feeling in the world," he stated matter-of-factly.

title: Joe Biden Wants to Undo a Rail Success
summary: Deregulation was a historic bipartisan triumph.. Have you heard about the bill steaming through a divided Congress with bipartisan support to reverse a 40-year bipartisan experiment in railroad deregulation? No, you haven't because it doesn't exist.

title: Privacy Protection Is in Florida's DNA
summary: Congress should follow Tallahassee's lead and make it a crime to steal someone else's genetic information.. Tallahassee, Fla.

title: All Haitian Migrants Cleared From Texas Border Camp
summary: Treatment of migrants draws bipartisan criticism; Biden says agents involved will face consequences. U.S. officials have emptied the makeshift camp of mostly Haitian migrants under a bridge in Del Rio, Texas, as the remaining migrants were deported or allowed to pursue their immigration cases in the U.S., according to Department of Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas.

title: Derek Chauvin Files Appeal of Murder Conviction for Killing of George Floyd
summary: Appeal cites 14 issues with trial in state court; former Minneapolis officer still faces federal civil-rights case. Former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin filed an appeal of his conviction for second-degree murder in the killing of George Floyd, which took place in May 2020 and set off a summer of protest and unrest across the U.S.

title: PG&E to Face Manslaughter Charges Over 2020 Wildfire
summary: Prosecutor files array of criminal charges against utility in connection with the Zogg Fire, which killed four people. A California prosecutor filed criminal charges including manslaughter against PG&E Corp. for its role in igniting a wildfire that killed four people last year.

title: Dow, S&P 500 Edge Higher After Evergrande Payment Deadline Passes
summary: Bitcoin prices fall after China's central bank declares all cryptocurrency-related transactions illegal. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 ticked up on Friday, clinching weekly gains despite uncertainty over the fate of indebted property giant China Evergrande Group .

title: Finance Chiefs Urge More Companies to Link Debt to Sustainability Goals
summary: A task force of CFOs associated with the United Nations wants to expand the market for debt linked to socially responsible targets. A group of finance chiefs from large international companies is urging peers to tie more of their companies' financing to corporate sustainability goals.

title: A Creepy, Cinematic Quartet
summary: Masaki Kobayashi's 'Kwaidan' recounts a series of supernatural encounters adapted from Japanese folklore.. A splash of flowing black ink fills the screen, leaving us without context or introduction. A red splash follows, then a blue one. What are we looking at here-or, rather, what does it mean? The images are abstract, and they're hypnotically beautiful. This is the beginning of "Kwaidan" (1965), Masaki Kobayashi's beguiling quartet of supernatural encounters adapted from Japanese folklore by a writer of Greek and Irish descent, Lafcadio Hearn.

title: Pelosi Plans Votes on Biden's Spending Plans Next Week Despite Democratic Rifts
summary: House speaker says party is engaged in 'intense dialogue' over infrastructure bill and education, healthcare and climate package. WASHINGTON-Top House Democrats said they would charge ahead with a plan to bring up both a $1 trillion infrastructure bill and a broad healthcare, education and climate package for a vote next week even as deep disagreements in the party threaten to scuttle the two bills.

title: GM Presses White-Collar Staff Who Haven't Reported Covid-19 Vaccination Status
summary: Auto maker says compliance rates have improved since internal memo went out Wednesday. General Motors Co. is cracking down on white-collar employees who haven't complied with a corporate mandate to report their vaccination status, illustrating the hurdles companies face in trying to navigate the sensitive topic of workforce immunity.

title: Schools With Face-Mask Requirements Had Fewer Covid-19 Outbreaks, CDC Study Finds
summary: Two studies suggest that masks can help prevent classroom outbreaks and pediatric cases in the community. Face-mask requirements in schools drastically reduce the spread of Covid-19 among children, two studies published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention suggest.

title: Biden Expresses Support for Annual Tax on Billionaires' Unrealized Gains
summary: Proposal is among provisions Democrats are pursuing to pay for proposed $3.5 trillion spending plan. WASHINGTON-President Biden expressed support for a proposal under consideration in the Senate to place an annual income tax on billionaires' unrealized capital gains.

title: 'The View' Co-Hosts Leave Set After Testing Positive for Covid-19
summary: Sunny Hostin, Ana Navarro were asked to leave stage minutes before Vice President Kamala Harris was due to appear. Two co-hosts of ABC's "The View" left the stage Friday morning because they tested positive for Covid-19, a fellow co-host said on air.

title: Minding the Shop (Saturday Crossword, September 25)
The Journal Acrostic (Saturday, September 25)
Jan. 6 Committee Issues Subpoenas to Four Former Trump Officials
summary: Mark Meadows, Steve Bannon, Dan Scavino and Kashyap Patel subpoenaed by House committee investigating assault on U.S. Capitol. WASHINGTON-The House Select Committee investigating the Jan. 6 assault on the U.S. Capitol issued subpoenas to four Trump administration officials, including former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows, seeking to compel them to turn over records and sit for depositions in connection with the events surrounding the attack.

title: New York City Readies Substitutes to Fill In for Unvaccinated Teachers
summary: Monday is city's deadline for school staffers to have at least one Covid-19 vaccine shot; union officials say up to 90% of educators have been inoculated. Thousands of New York City substitute teachers are on standby if some educators don't meet the Monday deadline to be vaccinated against Covid-19, Mayor Bill de Blasio said.

title: Petrofac to Plead Guilty to U.K. Bribery Charges
summary: Energy services company said it would plead guilty to seven counts of failing to prevent bribery at a hearing on Sept. 27. Petrofac Ltd. on Friday said it had reached a plea agreement with the U.K.'s Serious Fraud Office in relation to an investigation into the company's failure to prevent bribery.

title: The Delta Variant, Covid-19 Symptoms and Vaccine Efficacy: What to Know
summary: Places with higher vaccination rates are keeping hospitalizations and deaths in check. The Delta variant of the Covid-19 virus has driven up cases, hospitalizations and deaths across the U.S., particularly where vaccination rates are lower.

title: Ad Giant WPP to Pay $19 Million to Resolve SEC Investigation
summary: Regulator faults company's response to corruption signs in high-risk markets. Advertising giant WPP PLC will pay $19 million to resolve government allegations that it failed to adequately guard against corruption risks in India, China, Brazil and Peru, securities regulators announced Friday.

title: China Gives Neuberger Berman Nod to Launch Mutual Funds
summary: The asset manager joins BlackRock, Fidelity and other Wall Street firms seeking a share of the Chinese market. Neuberger Berman got the green light from Beijing to start its own mutual-fund business in China, paving the way for the American asset manager to manage money for individual Chinese investors.

title: Biden Hosts World Leaders to Share China Concerns
summary: Display of unity by U.S., Australia, India and Japan-known as the Quad-irks Beijing. WASHINGTON-Following recent moves that upset close allies, President Biden on Friday is attempting to strengthen an alliance with three countries that share concern about China's expanding clout in Asia.

title: Russian Gas Firm Executive Arrested in U.S. on Tax Charges
summary: Mark Gyetvay, an American who holds a Russian passport, evaded taxes for more than a decade, the U.S. charges. The U.S. has arrested a high-profile executive of a major Russian gas company on federal tax-evasion charges related to what federal officials said were violations that spanned more than a decade.

title: R. Kelly Jury Begins Deliberating in Racketeering Trial
summary: R&B singer is charged with leading a criminal enterprise and using his entourage to recruit women and girls for sex. A federal jury began deliberations Friday in the racketeering case against R&B singer R. Kelly, marking the final phase of the seven-week trial in Brooklyn.

title: Pharmacies Prepare for Broader Covid-19 Booster Distribution
summary: CVS, Walgreens say people will self-identify as meeting qualifications for third shots. Pharmacies and other Covid-19 vaccine providers prepared for a new surge in demand after federal officials widened booster eligibility to most people who say their health or job puts them at heightened risk of infection.

title: U.S. Issues Waivers Allowing Humanitarian Aid to Afghanistan
summary: U.S. agencies, aid groups and private sector can send food and medicine to the country. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration Friday said it would allow U.S. agencies, aid groups and the private sector to send food and medicine to Taliban-controlled Afghanistan, supplies that officials say are critical to address the country's growing humanitarian crisis.

title: CDC Chief Backs Pfizer Boosters for At-Risk Workers in Break With Panel
summary: Director Rochelle Walensky signs off on a series of recommendations for third Covid-19 shots. Pfizer Inc. booster doses will be available to millions of Americans after Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Director Rochelle Walensky backed the shots for seniors, many adults with underlying health conditions and workers at high risk of Covid-19 exposure.

title: Casino Pioneer Started in Garage
summary: Fred Dakota, who has died at age 84, challenged ban on casinos that kept them off tribal property. Fred Dakota expanded Native Americans' authority to operate and regulate their own businesses when he opened a casino in a two-car garage on a Michigan reservation in 1983.

title: Iraq Should Join the Abraham Accords
summary: Full relations with Israel would help atone for the infamous act of driving out our Jewish population.. Erbil, Iraq

title: Great Art Doesn't Care About Fairness, Equality or Identity
summary: On or about October 2015, human character changed. Inclusion trumped quality.. One of the most charming statements ever made about the development of art through the ages came from Virginia Woolf in 1924 in a talk at Cambridge University. "On or about December 1910 human character changed," Woolf said. Her subject was the modernist movement. She was speaking two years after the appearance of T.S. Eliot's seemingly impenetrable poem "The Waste Land." James Joyce's novel "Ulysses" had appeared at the same time. Picasso was already in his third or fourth phase of innovation. Stravinsky was being booed off the stage in Paris. A year after she addressed the students, Woolf herself published the impressionist novel "Mrs Dalloway"-a book in which both author and protagonist are subject to changes in "human character."

title: Port of Los Angeles Stops Short of 24-Hour Operations
summary: Gateway's director says truckers, other operators must first ramp up their overnight, weekend work as inbound containers swamp U.S. supply chains. The Port of Los Angeles is holding back on extending its gate hours as encouraged by the Biden administration, focusing instead on boosting efficiency in operations while coping with a surge in imports into the critical U.S. trade gateway.

title: Behind Covid-19 Booster Authorization Were Disagreements on Evidence, Broad Access
summary: Extra Pfizer doses are rolling out to certain adults after disputes inside the U.S. government and with its scientific advisers. The Biden administration publicly touted its plan to roll out Covid-19 boosters to almost all the fully vaccinated during the week of Sept. 20, saying data from Israel supported the approach.

title: Quilting America
summary: A new exhibition shows how craftspeople and artists, most of them women, turned quilts into a record of American history.. Piecework quilts have long been embedded, so to speak, in American life. Assembled from dozens, if not hundreds, of individual fabric pieces, their colorful geometries became popular in the decades before the Civil War, taking the place of wool "bed ruggs" and other colonial-era coverings. "Fabric of a Nation: American Quilt Stories," a new exhibition opening Oct. 10 at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, explores the enduring hold of quilts on the American imagination, with more than 50 textile works dating from the late 17th century to this year.

title: Police Officers Resist Getting Vaccinated for Covid-19, Now Their No. 1 Killer
summary: The disease is the leading cause of death among police, surpassing gunfire, but resistance persists. Police departments around the country are trying to persuade officers to get vaccinated against Covid-19 as their rates lag behind in communities they serve, but resistance persists despite efforts that include mandates.

title: U.S. Businesses on Canadian Border Want Their Customers Back
summary: Motels, retail stores and even sports teams like the Buffalo Bills football are seeing fallout from ongoing closure of the U.S. land border to Canadian tourists. MASSENA, N. Y.-It's late September, and Mike McCabe is getting ready to put down the first layers of ice on the arena in this village of about 10,000.

title: Ryder Cup on Course With Tech Overhaul
summary: 'Nobody would ever think there was this much technology in golf,' says the PGA of America's tech chief. Organizers of this week's Ryder Cup are leaning on a multiyear technology overhaul to deliver real-time golf scores and stats, live crowd and course maps, and other data services, bringing advanced analytics to a tradition-bound sport.

title: House Passes Measure to Protect Abortion Rights
summary: Bill, which would stop states from imposing curbs before fetal viability, is unlikely to advance in the Senate. WASHINGTON-The House passed legislation on Friday that would ban abortion restrictions before fetal viability, a response by Democrats to a recently enacted Texas law that bans the procedure after about six weeks of pregnancy.

title: Six Fall Getaways for Art Lovers, According to Art World Insiders
summary: Plus an extraordinary immersive museum in Japan well worth the wait. TO THE DELIGHT OF art lovers around the country, this autumn promises to be much livelier than last, with scores more museums fully open and long-delayed exhibits finally unfurled. But as coronavirus cases tick back up and restrictions tighten in some cities, elbowing your way through a crowded gallery at one of the country's major art institutions appeals far less than it used to. The solution? Seek out a less popular art venue with its own cachet. Better still, make it a pilgrimage and build a trip around the venture. After so many months deprived of both art and travel, what finer way to celebrate their return? For trip inspiration, we asked five art-world notables to share the collections and house-museums worth traveling for.

title: Home Builders Might Be a Home Run Once Supply Woes Ease
summary: Lumber prices drop, but materials and labor hold back supply and send U.S. new home prices higher. If only lumber had been all that was keeping home builders from selling more homes.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: The never-ending fall of Rome, Calvin Coolidge's quiet convictions, Jefferson Davis's right hand man and fiction from Richard Powers and Wole Soyinka..

title: Christmas Chaos: Shipping Delays Mean Santa Might Be Late This Year
summary: Resume Subscription. Klaus Müller-Blech is sending Christmas to Gettysburg, Pa., in a 1,000-foot long container ship. So far it's running three months late thanks to global transportation congestion.

title: Crypto Funds Trade in Coins Scrutinized by SEC
summary: Trying to benefit from sector's growth, wealthier investors buy financial products carrying legal and regulatory risk. WASHINGTON-Asset managers are offering funds that invest in cryptocurrencies whose legal viability has been questioned by regulators, underscoring the risks investors are taking to try to benefit from the sector's rapid growth.

title: AMC Fans Go Ape for Dogecoin, but Should Its Boss?
summary: Adam Aron might regret sourcing business ideas from his Twitter followers such as being able to buy popcorn with Dogecoin. The apes have spoken. Will they make a monkey out of this alpha male?

title: Foreign Businesses Say They Feel Effects From China's Turn Inward
summary: Multinationals are grappling with closed borders and favoritism toward local companies, business lobbies say. SINGAPORE-U.S. and European companies operating in China are feeling the effects as the country increasingly turns inward by keeping its borders closed and showing growing favoritism toward domestic companies, two business lobbies said in separate reports.

title: Patti Davis Has Wisdom to Share With Alzheimer's Caregivers
summary: In a new book, she offers lessons from her experience with her father, former president Ronald Reagan.. In the early 1990s, Patti Davis felt "broken and useless," she says. Her novels were earning tepid reviews, and acting jobs had dried up. "Everything I touched went bad," she recalls. Divorced and keen to escape an abusive relationship, she sold her Los Angeles home at the bottom of the market and fled to New York, where she knew almost no one. She says she thought seriously about suicide.

title: What Is Happening in Germany? An Election That Will Decide Angela Merkel's Successor
summary: For the first time since 2005, a German general election is too close to call, with the center-left holding a thin lead. German voters on Sunday will elect a new federal parliament-the first step toward appointing a successor to Angela Merkel. This marks the first time since 2002 that Ms. Merkel, one of Europe's longest-serving leaders, won't lead her party into a general election and the first time since World War II that a sitting German chancellor isn't seeking a new mandate.

title: The Campus Attack on ROTC, Then and Now
summary: 'Hostility to the military was so transparent on campus that for months I carried a uniform in my backpack.'. Ruth Wisse writes about the Reserve Officers' Training Corps from her perspective as a Harvard professor starting in 1993 ("Afghanistan Was Lost in the Halls of Harvard," op-ed, Sept. 21). It was even worse on U.S. campuses a decade earlier.

title: Noonan, Tolstoy and the Met Gala 'Freak Show'
summary: More than a fashion faux pas.. Peggy Noonan's fine article "America Has Lost the Thread" (Declarations, Sept. 18) includes the statement: "No nation can proceed in the world safely and fruitfully when at bottom it hates itself." This encapsulates perfectly what Tolstoy wrote in "Anna Karenina" (1878): "Only those nations have a future, only those nations can be called historical, that have a sense of what is important and significant in their institutions, and value them."

title: Which Came First, Sickness of the Soul or Decay of the City?
summary: Cicero might counsel that the individual is ailed by society.. Benjamin Storey and Jenna Silber Storey's lament of our modern society's "formlessness" and emphasis on "old, wise books" is a necessary breath of fresh air in today's academia, and Barton Swaim's profile of the couple is both erudite and timely ("Hope for the Lost Souls of Liberalism," Weekend Interview, Sept. 18). The classical thinkers Mr. Swaim mentions, however, would likely disagree with his conclusion: "You can't fix the city as long as the souls are a mess."

title: 2021 Jeep Wrangler Unlimited Rubicon 4xe: A Hybrid That Comes Up Short
summary: Jeep Wrangler's first plug-in hybrid for the U.S. market complicates the driving experience in pursuit of regulatory credits and buyer incentives. And for most drivers, writes Dan Neil, it will get poor fuel economy.. YEE-HAH. Eighty years after the original Willys Jeep set the template, Jeep's Wrangler compact SUV series is selling like there is no tomorrow, chalking up three straight quarters of record sales in the U.S., including 118,666 units in the first six months of 2021.

title: Early ADHD Diagnoses and the Decline of Men in College
summary: Boys develop low self-esteem and internalize low expectations.. Richard Vedder and Braden Colegrove offer four reasons "Why Men Are Disappearing on Campus" (op-ed, Sept. 20). A fifth is that we are drugging our boys from a young age. Of the many millions of U.S. children now diagnosed with ADHD, there are three times as many boys as girls. The drug treatments rob the children of their spontaneity and initiative, in addition to a host of other side effects. Moreover, when a child is told year after year by the adults he looks up to that he has ADHD-with some parents and teachers even saying the child "is ADHD"-the child may come to believe it, develop low self-esteem and internalize low expectations.

title: What Cuba Lost When Castro Drove Out So Many
summary: The contributions of the hundreds of thousands of exiles could have been given to our country of birth.. As a Cuban exile myself, I enjoyed reading Dr. Oscar Biscet's op-ed "Cubans Want Freedom, Not Exile" (Sept. 20). I came to the U.S. as a Cuban expatriate during the Mariel boatlift of 1980 because I, too, had a political dossier in Cuba.

title: Robinhood's Crypto Unit Hires New Chief Compliance Officer
summary: Appointment comes as Robinhood's crypto unit faces regulatory scrutiny. The cryptocurrency unit of popular trading platform Robinhood Markets Inc. has hired a new chief compliance officer, a move that comes as the company faces regulatory scrutiny.

title: Virus Research Has Exploded Since Covid-19 Hit. Is It Safe?
summary: Resume Subscription. Laboratories around the globe increasingly are experimenting with emerging viruses, sometimes giving them new capabilities, as they seek to identify dangerous ones and find ways to combat them.

title: Merkel Says Auf Wiedersehen to a Diminished Europe
summary: The long-serving German chancellor helped the EU survive a string of crises, but her caution and focus on her own country's interests have undermined the continent's once-grand aspirations. When Angela Merkel barely scraped her way into office as Germany's chancellor in 2005, Europe's largest economy was stalled, with unemployment at a postwar high and Germans fearful that their industrial powerhouse was fading amid growing global competition.

title: What the 'Smart Money' Knows About China's Evergrande Crisis
summary: On Wall Street, hype almost always leads to heartache. Investors who hopped on the China bandwagon are learning that lesson the hard way.. NOBODY KNOWS ANYTHING.

title: Evergrande's Global Bondholders Didn't Receive Interest Payment
summary: Chinese property developer was on the hook to make $83.5 million in coupon payments by Thursday. Global investors who own China Evergrande Group 's U.S. dollar bonds hadn't received an interest payment from the property giant by Thursday's deadline, said people familiar with the matter.

title: China's Xinjiang Crackdown Reaps Millions of Dollars in Assets for the State
summary: Courts sell off property and company shares once belonging to jailed Uyghur business owners. KORLA, China-Chinese authorities have seized and sold at auction tens of millions of dollars in assets owned by jailed Uyghur business owners amid a broad government campaign to assimilate ethnic minorities in the country's northwest Xinjiang region.

title: 'The Eternal Decline and Fall of Rome' Review: The Road From Ruin
summary: The useful tale of the Roman world's collapse and defeat has lasted longer than any empire.. This is a history of Rome in which the first name is that of Donald Trump and Ronald Reagan's name almost the last. President Trump earns his place with his inaugural address promising to "make America great again," President Reagan with a speech in 1969 on the theme of "decline and fall" in which the greatest empire in Western history collapsed in bureaucracy, excessive welfare payments, taxes on the middle class and long-haired students wearing makeup. Edward J. Watts, a professor of history at the University of California, San Diego, is a scholar of the later ancient world, who takes his readers from republican Rome to Republican Washington with a resounding theme that anyone promising to restore lost greatness is probably up to no good.

title: M&A Banker Found Promise in Nascent Biotechnology Companies
summary: Fred Frank crafted Roche's landmark deal with Genentech. In 1983, Amgen Inc., then a startup in the fledgling biotechnology industry, was running out of money after raising millions from venture-capital firms. Fred Frank, a partner at Lehman Brothers, suggested the company stage an initial public offering, sensing it had promise. Amgen executives laughed at the idea, given that the firm had no products.

title: 'The Autobiography of Calvin Coolidge' Review: Quiet, Modest, Memorable
summary: Coolidge's character was a contrast to Jazz Age ebullience.. The ordinary reader may be forgiven for concluding that modern presidential memoirs are meant to be talked about, not read. They attempt to offer a comprehensive and idealized version of the protagonist's life and time in office but fail to say much of anything memorable. Nobody would read Lyndon Johnson's "The Vantage Point" or Jimmy Carter's "Keeping Faith" for reasons other than research. Richard Nixon's "RN" and Bill Clinton's "My Life" bury their insights in an ocean of forgettable words. George W. Bush's "Decision Points," the best and most readable presidential memoir since Harry Truman's, is a partial exception here-it contains fewer than 500 pages. But it, too, could lose some weight; nobody now wants to read about, for example, the 43rd president's Malaria Initiative. I haven't yet read "A Promised Land," the first volume of Barack Obama's account of his time in the Oval Office, but I fail to see how a man can write more than 700 pages and get no further than the third year of his presidency.

title: Fiction: 'Bewilderment' and 'When We Cease to Understand the World'
summary: Two very different works of fiction follow scientists whose knowledge is put to the test.. Some trivia to begin: Bitter almonds contain a compound called amygdalin, which, when ingested, releases trace amounts of the lethal poison cyanide. This factoid comes compliments of two recent works of fiction-"Bewilderment," by Richard Powers, and "When We Cease to Understand the World," by Chilean writer Benjamín Labatut-where it has been put to use in ways suggestive of two vastly different visions of humankind's relationship with science.

title: 'Judah Benjamin' Review: The Ultimate Outsider
summary: Arguably the most important American Jew of the 19th century, he deserves our attention, but not our admiration.. The career of Judah P. Benjamin (1811-1884), the Jewish son of the South who lent his legal brilliance to the Confederacy as its secretary of state and chief adviser to its president, Jefferson Davis, has long troubled me. That Benjamin-or any Jew, North or South-would defend slavery simply does not jibe with my practice or understanding of Jewish tradition. Doesn't the Bible teach us to remember that we, too, had once been slaves in Egypt, and command us to commemorate the journey of the Exodus from bondage to freedom by retelling the saga each spring on the holiday of Passover?

title: 'Chronicles From the Happiest People on Earth' Review: Nigeria Now
summary: A Nobel laureate arrives with his first novel in half a century.. Trapped inside the bulk of Wole Soyinka's new novel, the Nobel laureate's first in almost 50 years, is the story of a man who has risen from a rural backwater to become one of Nigeria's most accomplished surgeons. But privileged and well connected though he is, he cannot make sense of the corruption and violence around him. He is haunted also by his memory of the time he agreed to use his skills not to heal but to punish.

title: China Declares Crypto Transactions Illegal, Sending Bitcoin Lower
summary: The move reinforces China's tough stance, the strongest to date from a major economy against the use of digital currencies. China's central bank said all cryptocurrency-related transactions are illegal, reinforcing the country's tough stance against digital rivals to government-issued money.

title: Mysteries: Richard Osman's 'The Man Who Died Twice' Review
summary: Seniors are on the case in a return outing for the 'Thursday Murder Club.'. The Thursday Murder Club, a group of seniors who live in a retirement home and unofficially investigate cold and warm criminal cases, was introduced last year in English author Richard Osman's bestselling debut novel. The club makes a triumphant return in Mr. Osman's "The Man Who Died Twice."

title: EQT Faces Probe Over Disclosure of Share Sale
summary: Sweden's regulator said the private-equity firm had held back on disclosing that it allowed partners to sell shares earlier than initially planned. Buyout giant EQT AB, one of Europe's best stock-market performers this year, is under investigation by Sweden's regulator for potential market abuse over the timing of its disclosure that it allowed its partners to sell about $2.7 billion of stock a year ahead of schedule.

title: Sheltering With Thoreau
summary: The writer said wealth is 'not possession but enjoyment.' Twenty-seven modern followers share the wealth.. Almost 180 years ago, Henry David Thoreau did, voluntarily and cheerfully, what many of us were forced to do last year: He took shelter. On July 4, 1845, he moved into his cabin near Walden Pond in Concord, Mass., where he lived alone for two years and two months, "solely by the labor of my hands." Well, mostly. Lionized by generations of nature enthusiasts, Thoreau has had plenty of detractors, too, deeming him a hypocrite for dining at the Emersons' or having his mom take care of his wash. And then there is what David Gessner, in "Quiet Desperation, Savage Delight," calls Thoreau's "imperative voice," directing us where to live, what to eat and how to dress. All of which makes Thoreau's "Walden" (1854) one of the hardest texts to teach. "Arrogant," is the verdict I hear, frequently, from undergraduates. Who does he think he is?

title: The Playoff Race Is Wide Open in College Football. The Pandemic Is Still to Blame.
summary: Every team that's become synonymous with semifinal appearances looks uncharacteristically shaky, including Alabama. After a chaotic 2020 season that robbed college football of much of its pageantry, teams are back to playing predictable schedules with big-time non-conference games in front of packed stadiums. But the pandemic is not done monkeying with college football.

title: 'Conquering the Pacific' Review: Sailing Against the Wind
summary: Pioneering Spanish mariners crossed the Pacific to the Philippines. Finding a route back was harder.. Perhaps the most audacious act of mapping in history took place in 1494. The age of exploration was in its infancy and Europeans had only vague notions of what lay beyond their little corner of the world. Pope Alexander VI, throwing all caution to the wind, drew a line from pole to pole in the Atlantic Ocean and divided the world between Spain and Portugal. Diplomats ratified the decision by treaty in the Spanish town of Tordesillas and a race was on between the two empires to chart and claim their halves of the world.

title: Five Best: Mysteries in the Academy
summary: Selected by David Bell, the author, most recently, of the novel 'Kill All Your Darlings.'. By Stephen L. Carter (2007)

title: EV Battery Investments Are Getting More Political
summary: Mercedes-Benz and Ford have both made bets this week on unproven battery companies. What they offer instead is localism.. Car makers' battery investments took a nativist turn this week. That isn't a surprising development, but it brings extra risks.

title: CNN's Chris Cuomo Accused of Sexually Harassing a Former ABC News Producer
summary: Shelley Ross said Mr. Cuomo touched her inappropriately at a party in 2005; he said that he apologized for the incident and that it wasn't sexual in nature. A veteran TV journalist said Friday that CNN anchor Chris Cuomo groped her in 2005 while they were both employees of Walt Disney Co. 's ABC News.

title: Children's Books: Drama Behind the Iron Curtain
summary: The contradictions-and dangers-of growing up under totalitarianism come to life for young readers.. When Victor Yelchin was a boy in Cold War-era Moscow, he was so thrilled to receive a stick of Juicy Fruit gum from an American tourist that he chewed it for three weeks. "By the time I inherited the gum," his younger brother Eugene remembers, "it had neither taste nor smell." "The Genius Under the Table" is Eugene Yelchin's idiosyncratic illustrated memoir of boyhood behind the Iron Curtain, a chronicle that manages to amuse with its quirky details and disturb with the broad picture it paints of life under communism.

title: HNA Group Chairman Chen Feng, CEO Adam Tan Detained by Police
summary: Chinese conglomerate says its operations aren't affected, restructuring work continues. Embattled Chinese conglomerate HNA Group said Friday that its chairman Chen Feng and Chief Executive Adam Tan are suspected of committing crimes and have been detained.

title: Some Species Are Changing Along With the Climate
summary: Warmer conditions have prompted animals and plants to adopt new habits and evolve new traits: Squid are shrinking, lizards are growing bigger toes and trees are migrating. Amid the ice floes of the Arctic, tiny seabirds called dovekies feed in the plankton-rich waters, a survival strategy that worked well until the pack ice began to dwindle around the islands in Russia's Franz Josef Land, where the dovekies breed. Like their Arctic neighbors the polar bears, often seen stranded on shrinking icebergs, it appeared that the dovekies faced an existential threat because of climate change. Scientists working in the region predicted that they would have to fly an hour or more to find food.

title: China's Online Game Companies Fall in Line With Restrictions on Entertainment
summary: Tencent, NetEase and others vow to self-regulate and prevent young players from circumventing game-time regulations. Hundreds of Chinese online game companies have vowed to self-regulate and combat user addiction, the country's state-backed gaming industry association said, falling in line with a government effort to restrict negative influences from entertainment on China's youth.

title: Beijing Olympics Is on Course to Have Stricter Covid-19 Rules Than Tokyo
summary: Early steps taken by China to safeguard its 'National Games' have raised the prospect of intense measures for people arriving in the country. With just over four months to go until the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics, the developing picture of the Games is one of severe Covid-19 restrictions for outsiders, and possible advantages for domestic athletes.

title: 'Dear Evan Hansen': High School Musical Muddle
summary: The blockbuster Broadway show hits some sour notes in its move to the big screen.. 'Dear Evan Hansen," the screen version of the acclaimed Broadway musical, draws its dramatic energy from the anguish of its young hero, a high-school senior who suffers from a severe anxiety disorder. Painfully lonely and terrified of the rejection that he constantly courts, Evan thinks in obsessive loops and speaks in apologetic whispers, though he sings ardently, sometimes beautifully, of his fears and yearnings. He's played by Ben Platt, who began to develop the role in 2014, then went on to win a Tony for his brilliance on stage. You needn't have seen the show-I did not-to understand how powerful his performance must have been. But the film suffers from a different condition, an emotional elephantiasis that is inexorable and ultimately terminal. What was by all accounts a modestly scaled production in all of its live-theater iterations has become a ponderous movie that turns earnest into maudlin, lyrical into lugubrious.

title: Bitcoin, Nike, Meredith, Carnival: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Bitcoin was sinking on a crackdown in China; Nike said production woes were hurting sales. Futures are edging down and bond yields are up to multi-month highs, as uncertainty lingers about heavily indebted property giant China Evergrande Group . Here's what we're watching ahead of Friday's opening bell.

title: Starbucks Faces Rare Union Challenge in Upstate New York
summary: Workers in some Buffalo cafes cite concerns about pay and staffing; Starbucks says it is boosting wages and benefits and a union isn't needed. Starbucks Corp. is pushing back against an employee unionization drive as workers at some Buffalo, N.Y., stores attempt to become the first company-owned cafes in the U.S. to organize.

title: As Delta Variant Surges, Workers With Health Issues Face Tough Choices
summary: Most Popular News. For Brooklyn teacher Kathryn Malara, this month feels like the most difficult time in the pandemic.

title: How Jon Hamm and Rob Dyrdek Stay Resilient
summary: The 'Mad Men' star and MTV host join four other luminaries to weigh in on what resilience means to them in this month's Columnists. "Having lost both my parents at a relatively early age is a big reminder of the importance not only of personal resilience and wherewithal, but also the importance of-and the okayness of-needing other people to help you along your journey. We have this unique American outlook of the sort of rugged outsider and the cowboy and the guy who only depends on himself. That's more and more a myth that I think has been de-bunked. If you look at most kind of classic depictions of cowboys, it's sad. Maybe they have a dog and a horse. That's pretty much it. I lost my mother at 10 and my father at 20. I've had very close family friends and teachers and other people who filled in [in] that capacity in my life. I was wise enough, I guess, at a young age to understand that that's just as good."

title: The Perfect Outfits for All of Your Park Hangouts this Autumn
summary: Outerwear gets a funky remix with psychedelic colors and free-spirited silhouettes.. The playful, carefree nature of this fall's collections comes to life with an energetic mix of exuberant daywear that makes getting noticed a walk in the park. As envisioned by stylist Stella Greenspan and photographer Nick Sethi, models Sebastian Cooper and Arianna Martinez show that a never-grow-up look in a kaleidoscope of colors can be lots of fun. Bright hues and unexpected textures keep things lively, including extra-fuzzy bright purple knits from Dolce & Gabbana and Junya Watanabe. Hot pink pieces come from Dior Men and Bottega Veneta while Ermenegildo Zegna XXX, Hermès and The Elder Statesman all prove it is pretty easy to be green. Cornflower-blue pants by Dries Van Noten and a sapphire-hued sequin skirt from Vaquera round out the rainbow. Cloud-like, extra-light outerwear from Miu Miu, Givenchy and Kwaidan Editions make puffy pieces seem weightless, while standout shoes and boots from Balenciaga, Gucci and Givenchy finish things off with a bang. -Kevin Huynh

title: Lorna Simpson Never Stops Inventing
summary: The multimedia artist's new exhibition at Hauser & Wirth Los Angeles, 'Everrrything,' isn't "about" anything. "Everything is on the table, everything is a mess, everything is at risk," she says.. Growing up in Brooklyn and Queens, artist Lorna Simpson remembers the many museums throughout New York she visited with her parents. To this day, she keeps a photograph that shows her mother, then pregnant with her, standing next to a sculpture at the Guggenheim, taken by her father. Her family, she says, was the first to ignite her love for art.

title: Trapped Afghan Women Fear Retribution Under Taliban Rule
summary: Resume Subscription. KABUL-Nabila, a 31-year-old Afghan judge, used to grant divorces to the wives of militants while their husbands languished in prison. Two days after the Taliban captured Kabul on Aug. 15 and emptied prisons across the country, she received threatening calls from several of these men.

title: Apple Faces Off With Europe Regulators Over Phone Chargers
summary: EU is proposing a single phone charger technology that would effectively ban the iPhone-maker's 'Lightning' port. The European Union proposed a bloc-wide common charging standard for smartphones and other electronic devices, a move that, if adopted, would effectively bar the use of Apple Inc.'s unique "Lightning" charging port now used for all of its new smartphones.

title: 7 Old-School Interior Design Trends That 'Grandmillennials' Are Revitalizing
summary: From allover pattern to framed botanicals, the décor ideas that designers who love 'granny chic' are bringing down from the attic. THOUGH 35, Whitney McGregor considers herself an old soul, an identity she shares with many young people drawn to unmodern things. The Greenville, S.C., designer-one of many self-identifying grandmillennials giving new life to traditional décor-embraces florals on florals and doesn't quail in the face of scallop-trim.

title: What People Should Leave Off Their Résumés (but Rarely Do)
summary: Some experiences are almost always irrelevant, and should be eliminated to make room for more important things. Lynda Spiegel is a founder of Rising Star Résumés, a résumé and job-search coaching service. She spent 15 years as a human-resources professional.

title: China Airlift Mission Shows Off Capabilities in Disputed Sea
summary: A recent air transport maneuver in the South China Sea shows Beijing's bases on disputed reefs can handle large aircraft, unsettling a neighbor. SINGAPORE-An air transport mission by China's military to island bases in the South China Sea has drawn a rebuke from Vietnam and raised concerns among security experts that Beijing is trying to normalize its activities in the disputed waters.

title: Iowa GOP Sen. Chuck Grassley to Seek Re-election
summary: Oldest Republican senator's decision to seek eighth term could boost GOP prospects to retake Senate. Sen. summary: DoorDash and Uber Eats are rapidly expanding into alcohol delivery. Eighteen months into the pandemic, food-delivery platforms are betting everyone could use a drink.

summary: Party proposals don't affect main reasons why profitable companies sometimes report no current U.S. tax costs. WASHINGTON-President Biden's talking points on corporate taxes often revolve around a list of 55 profitable U.S. companies that didn't pay income taxes in 2020.

title: Nike Can Handle Vietnam, but Watch China
summary: Supply-chain delays will throw obstacles in Nike's way, but those issues are manageable compared to any lost market share in China. Vietnam's factory closures are stealing the show at Nike , but investors might want to focus elsewhere in Asia.

summary: Lauren Hobart, the retailer's first nonfamily CEO, talks about her 'people first' approach. Lauren Hobart took the top job at Dick's Sporting Goods Inc. earlier this year, becoming one of a few dozen female CEOs to helm America's largest companies and the third person to run the family-owned retailer since its start in 1948.

title: Toast Is Hot, but Software Is the Jam
summary: After a sizzling public offering for the restaurant-technology provider, investors should be looking closely at its subscription-software business. Investors gobbled up slices of the restaurant technology upstart Toast this week. They should look for more flavor before taking any more bites.

title: Apollo Unit Backs Hong Kong Insurer FWD's U.S. IPO
summary: Asia's growing insurance markets have given rise to some of the world's most valuable insurers. Hong Kong tycoon Richard Li's FWD Group Holdings landed a $400 million investment as part of the Asian insurer's plans for a multibillion-dollar U.S. listing.

title: China Needs to Kick its Coal Habit at Home, Too
summary: Xi Jinping's pledge to cease financing coal plants abroad is good for the environment and makes business sense, too. But progress at home is the real key.. China's pledge to stop financing coal-fired power plants abroad is a welcome move, though the elephant in the room-a very large, sooty one-is at home.

title: Can the Ryder Cup Cool Off Golf's Big Feud?
summary: Brooks Koepka and Bryson DeChambeau aren't about to start fan clubs for each other. This weekend they're on the same team, trying to win glory for the U.S.. Is there a funnier bit of terminology than "golf feud?"

summary: In another sign of market froth, a fractional guitar-ownership program from Gibson gives rock enthusiasts a way to combine business and pleasure. Space-tourism companies, flying-taxi startups and pizza-related cryptocurrencies are among the unlikely ventures to have recently reached public markets. Now it is the turn of electric guitars.

title: Retirement Savers Love the Backdoor Roth IRA Strategy. It Might Not Last.
summary: With Congress looking to rein in Roth conversions, the tax-saving option could go away. Many Americans are using a previously little-known tax method to boost their savings. Now, the government is trying to stop it.

title: Democrats Hunt for Redistricting Wins Despite GOP Tilt
summary: As maps start to take shape, Democrats use legal, legislative and political moves to try to improve their position. DEMOCRATS CLAW FOR SEATS as they face an uphill battle in redistricting. Republicans hold the pen in 20 of the 35 states where legislatures control redistricting and the state has more than one congressional seat, compared with Democratic control of 11 such states, so Democrats are using legal, legislative and political maneuvers to try to improve their position as maps start to take shape.

title: Commerce Secretary Aims to Strengthen Ties With China
summary: In interview, Raimondo says U.S. commercial engagement with China could ease political tensions; some China watchers are skeptical. WASHINGTON-Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said she would seek to improve U.S. business ties with China, seeing mutual benefit at a time of increasing tensions between the two nations over national-security and human-rights issues.

title: Evergrande Auditor Gave Clean Bill of Health Despite Debt
summary: PwC didn't include a going-concern warning in its annual report for the ailing property developer. Last year as China Evergrande Group 's stock and bond prices seesawed, it offered deep discounts to keep sales growing during the pandemic and the government effectively said it had borrowed too much.

summary: Earlier this year, government officials told the company to come up with a plan to substantially cut back on its media holdings. Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. plans to dispose of its minority ownership in a state-owned broadcaster, the first concrete step the Chinese internet giant is taking to dismantle its sprawling media empire following pressure from Beijing.

title: How the U.S. Debt Ceiling Works
summary: Congress faces a looming deadline to raise the debt ceiling and prevent a default on the national debt. Congress must reach a deal to raise the federal borrowing limit, or debt ceiling, before the government runs out of money to pay its bills by mid-October. The House passed a measure keeping the government funded until early December and suspending its borrowing limit through 2022, but the bill faces an uphill battle in the Senate.

title: House Passes Defense-Policy Bill With Military-Justice Provision
summary: The National Defense Authorization Act, which authorizes a 5% boost in spending, is expected to draw broad bipartisan support. WASHINGTON-The House passed a $777.9 billion annual defense-policy bill Thursday by a 316-113 vote, authorizing more funding for the Pentagon than President Biden had requested, while also tackling thorny debates related to draft registration and military sexual assaults.

title: Chip Shortage Is Focus of White House Meeting
summary: Biden administration urges companies to volunteer information about their supply chains. title: Alaska Implements Crisis Care Protocols as Hospital Beds Dwindle
summary: Covid-19 patients make up more than 20% of those hospitalized in Alaska, and the state's largest hospital has started rationing care. Hospitals across Alaska can begin rationing and prioritizing medical resources after officials activated crisis standards of care Wednesday. It is the second state to do so this month as the number of patients hospitalized with Covid-19 is on the rise in some states.

title: Democratic Leaders Scramble to Find Areas of Agreement on $3.5 Trillion Spending Bill
summary: Disagreements between the party's centrist and liberal factions could delay a separate $1 trillion infrastructure package. WASHINGTON-Democratic leaders raced Thursday to find enough agreement around a roughly $3.5 trillion spending package to assuage concerns between the party's dueling centrist and liberal factions that threatened to derail a separate vote on an infrastructure package next week.

title: U.S. Special Envoy for Haiti Resigns in Midst of Migrant Crisis
summary: Departure of Daniel Foote, a career diplomat, comes as Washington deals with surge of Haitian migrants. The U.S. special envoy for Haiti, Ambassador Daniel Foote, has resigned his post in protest over the Biden administration's decision to conduct large-scale deportations in response to a surge of Haitian migrants.
